choices.B: MY_PROC1 is recompiled but remains unchanged.
choices.D: MY_PROC1 is recompiled without the debugging code.
choices.C: MY_PROC2 is recompiled but remains unchanged.

comments.content: Nope. sail_alwiliy is right, answer is C & D.

discussion.content: It should be B and C.
who can shine some lights on this question?

comments.content:
Using Static Constants
http://docs.oracle.com/cd/B19306_01/appdev.102/b14261/fundamentals.htm – BABIHIHF

“Changing the value of one of the constants forces all the dependent units of the package to recompile with the new value. For example, changing the value of debug to FALSE would cause my_proc1 to be recompiled without the debugging code. my_proc2 would also be recompiled, but my_proc2 would be unchanged because the value of trace did not change.”

choices.B: The SQL does not support the Boolean data type.
choices.C: A null value cannot be applied to the bind arguments in the using clause in line 10.
choices.A: The assignment in line 7 is not valid.
choices.D: The names of bind variables must be the same as the using clause bind arguments in line 10.

discussion.content: Starting from 12c this code executes without errors.
in 12c, it executes with no error, but no rows are updated in the table because v_empno is still null;
But pl/sql supports boolean data type, i dont see the problem here, can somone help ?

comments.content: now I see, the assignment in line 7 is wrong, v_job is a normal variable, not a host variable so it must be written without ":"
SQL doesnt support the data type BOOLEAN as returning type of a function.

questions.question_text:
View the Exhibit and examine the structure of the departments table in SCOTTs schema.
//IMG//

Examine the following block of code:
CREATE OR REPLACE PROCEDURE add_dept(
p_id NUMBER, p_name VARCHAR2) IS

BEGIN -
INSERT INTO departments VALUES <p_id, p_name, NULL, NULL);
END;
/
The above procedure is created by user SCOTT. Another user JONES needs to use the procedure.
Which two statements are true in the above scenario? (Choose two.)

comments.content: it means EXECUTE, and in these case is typo error.

choices.D: SCOTT should grant both the BXKCOTE privilege for the procedure and insert privilege for the table to
choices.B: JONES executes the procedure with invoker's rights.
choices.A: JONES executes the procedure with definer's rights.
choices.C: SCOTT should grant only the execute privilege for the procedure to JONES.

choices.D: Statement triggers are useful if the trigger action depends on the data of rows that are affected or on data that is provided by the triggering event itself.
choices.C: Row triggers are useful if the trigger action depends on the data of rows that are affected or on data that is provided by the triggering event itself.
choices.A: A row trigger fires once even if no rows are affected.
choices.B: A statement trigger fires once even if no rows are affected.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about statement-level and row-level triggers? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Note down:
Statement Level Trigger will execute 1 and only 1 time, for updating (delete or inserte as well) 0 or n rows. Even, Row Level Trigger will execute 0 or n times, for updating (delete or inserte as well), 0 or n rows respectively.

choices.D: Both the DBMS_DDL package and the Wrap utility can obfuscate multiple programs at a time.
choices.B: SQL' Plus cannot process the obfuscated source files.
choices.A: The Import and Export utilities accept wrapped files.
choices.C: Only the wrap utility can obfuscate multiple programs at a time.
choices.E: The source code is visible only through the DBA_SOURCE view and not through the USER_SOURCE or ALL_SOURCE View

questions.question_text: Identify two features of obfuscation. (Choose two.)
